newsitem.title: USA: U.S. considering more food aid for N. Korea.
newsitem.headline: U.S. considering more food aid for N. Korea.

text.p: The United States said on Wednesday it was considering more food aid for North Korea following a new appeal by the U.N. World Food Programme.

Washington has responded positively to all previous WFP appeals and as for the latest appeal "we're going to give this very serious consideration," State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns told a news briefing.
Burns said there was "some degree of urgency" to the food shortages faced by North Korea's Stalinist regime and so a formal U.S. response to the WFP appeal was expected shortly.
The WFP earlier on Wednesday launched an appeal for an additional $46 million in food aid to boost supplies the United Nations is sending for some 2.6 million children younger than 6.
Catherine Bertini, the head of the programme, told reporters that tens of thousands of North Korean children are "wasting away" from malnutrition and many seem doomed to die.

Although this year's rice harvest was shaping up well, it could not provide enough for the Communist state to feed its 24 million people without continuing outside help, she said. The United States this year has given the WFP $25 million in response to earlier appeals for North Korea.
